page.title: 06LUTON REMEMBERED
page.content: On July 1st I interviewed an old man. I gave him a list of questions but he did not answer them, he just went on and this is what he told me. Montrose Avenue was once a small lane. THe Biscot Mill was once a real mill. From the Biscot Mill to New Bedford Road was all cornfields. People had to pay road charges. Houses have not changed at all. The garden was really an old piece of old land. There were five cinemas, one in Park Street, Mill Street, High Town, Dunstable Road and Gordon Street. It was six pence to go to the cinema in the old days. One person in ten had got a car. After the second world war there were street parties in St. Michaels and St.Ethelberts. A car in those days cost Â£100. A good wage was Â£3.50 in 1935. A house cost about Â£750.
